ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I did not think the final assignment, the "pocket guide to interdisciplinarity," was an especially good one. We would have been much better off designing our own recovery plans.
The course's material is valuable to any discipline and should be taught more widely in FES.

Susan brought in several guest lecturers throughout the semester who were great. The field trip to the peabody collections was awesome too. I also enjoyed the assignments - particularly the review of a ESA recovery plan - and thought that all assignments were very aplicable to what were learning in class.
The guest speakers who talked about their experience and the need for interdisciplinarity in their works.

The guest speakers -- especially Rich Wallace and Dave Mattson -- were dynamic and engaging, and really helped make some of Susan's more abstract statements tangible and real. I also really enjoyed the recovery plan critique assignment, which allowed us to implement some of the mental frameworks that we developed in the class.
* The talks given by guests and students were always very interesting and insightful.
The material was taught through conceptual terms and also in case studies. Additionally students were allowed to apply the concepts to their own experiences in their lives or their research.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: In the beginning of the semester I would have appreciated a little bit more structure. I know Susan is not big on lecturing but maybe split up the class so its half lecture and then half discussion. Also, incorporating more case studies within the interdisciplinary framework might help facilitate discussion. It can be hard to have an engaging discussion for readings that were strictly on the policy sciences.
It will be great if the professor can have students analyze more than one policy in the future.

The class didn't really seem to follow any logical pattern. Class sessions often veered far off course, as the instructor sometimes engaged in stream-of-consciousness monologues about topics only tangentially related to the subject matter. I often left class sessions with no idea of what had just happened. All too often, the instructor would initiate a promising discussion thread; and then, instead of facilitating discussion, answer her own question or take the conversation in some unpredictable and hard-to-follow direction. This grew very frustrating.

The class was poorly structured. Having readings and discussions during class was helpful, but not enforced. The final assignment was a good exercise, but was not rigorous enough to make us fully understand the basis of interdisciplinarity.I would suggest to keep the course as focused as to reading the case study book and discussing it in depth. The readings and other smaller side assignments were a bit distracting from the main goal of the class.
A clearer structure of how the class moves forward and clearer expectations on assignments

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Through email the TA was very available and helpful

Susan and Jon were always available and both were very generous with their time. Susan's great in that she actually makes you come to her office at least once but I found myself dropping in quite a bit.
Both the professor and the TA were available and were very helpful.
I did not seek out either for help -- perhaps this was a mistake. They both gave the impression of being available, though.

InstructorWhenever we had the chance to meet, she was extremely insightful and willing to share her time. This is a key aspect of Susan, your questions are addressed and furthered during conversations with her.TAVERY responsive to e-mails, available for meetings and in general helpful and insightful.
The TA and instructor were available to meet and were generally very helpful with questions I brought.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I think this course was very relevant, the material was completely new to me and I feel it will be very helpful to me in the future.

I needed at least one social science course for my program and had heard from lots of students - current and past - to take one of Susan's courses. I also really didn't know anything about species conservation in the U.S. and being interested in land management I thought it was important that I knew something about it.
This course is very valuable in the type of work I pursue in the future as I will be dealing with diverse groups of people.
I'm interested in conservation and wildlife management -- I'm not sure whether or not I will pursue it professionally, but I might, and at the very least I'd like to know how it's conducted.
This course address what I'm interested in specifically, but it could be applied to anyone studying environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above response.
To learn to use the knowledge in the field that I am interested to work in effectively and efficiently so that it lasts for a very long time.

I thought the subject matter would be interesting and applicable to my interests, and I thought that Susan Clark's perspective, famed as it is, would be a useful one to experience. Like Susan, I believe strongly in the power of interdisciplinarity to help solve environmental problems, and I wanted to learn how to apply that framework.
Recommendations from previous students

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes

For the most part yes. I think the framework Susan teaches is great and spot on. This is truly a professional class in that you learn this interdisciplinary framework and how to apply it to natural resource problems. I do wish we spent a little more time on the species and ecosystem conservation side of things since Susan has so much experience in that field but overall it was a great course and I got a lot out of it.

Not really. Frankly, my understanding of what is meant by the term "interdisciplinarity" isn't much clearer than it was three months ago. I think a big part of the problem is that there have been very few cases of its successful use in species conservation. Nearly all the cases we studied were negative -- cases in which interdisciplinarity was not practiced, and species did not recover as a result. Seeing a positive case -- i.e., the successful application of an ID framework -- would have crystallized things for me, and, I think, for the rest of the class. Maybe it isn't the instructor's fault that there are few examples, but it was still frustrating.
Definitely

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes, see above.

In some ways. I definitely learned a lot about how to go about species recovery -- if you told me tomorrow to devise a recovery plan, I'd be much better equipped to do so. At the same time, I feel like there's a lot of knowledge out there that I could have acquired, but didn't. I thought that many of the readings and class sessions were redundant.
I got more out of the class than I expected. It challenged me to change how I think, and moreover to think about how I think.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you're on the fence about taking the course, don't be intimidated by the first class - things will pick up. Go see Susan often - she's great to talk to. Start reviewing your recovery plan early in the semester. It will make your presentation that much better and you'll get more out of the experience if you do.
The text book is very very useful.

You have to work really hard to stay with Susan's train of thought. She's obviously incredibly intelligent and experienced; but her hyperactive mind and body of knowledge is exactly what make her tough to follow. If you just let her go on tangents,you'll lose the thread. You have to constantly ask questions, challenge her, make sure she's explaining things clearly... this is all much easier said than done, though.
I would suggest students to take the Foundations class Susan offers during the Fall semester. This will enhance your enjoyment and understanding of the topics of the class.
Ask for clarification on the structure of the class and assignments
